ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Niko Alexandre
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  I interacted a lot with both the Professor and his TA
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Niko
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Overall, Niko was a helpful and accessible TA. I appreciated his presence in the class.
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Alexandre Nikola
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Niko is responsive and insightful.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  He understood the subject very well
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Niko was very helpful in keeping the class organized and reminding us about assignments and field trip details.
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Niko was somewhat slow to respond to emails but once he responded, the feedback was typically helpful.

Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  Niko was great at leading discussion and asking interesting questions to promote thoughtful dialogue. However, he didn't always communicate feedback on materials and seemed a bit disorganized.
Instructor: Nikola Alexandre  The teaching assistant graded and provided feedback on assignments thoroughly and posted course content in a timely manner.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: N/A
The Professor has a lot of experience which added valuable perspective to the course.

David is definitely a knowledgeable and innovative planner, but the course was somewhat disorganized. The assignments were vague and unclear and it felt like the entire design of the class could have been thought through a little better in advance. The flexibility of the final paper was appreciated, but the first two assignments didn't really exist at the time the syllabus was written, and were invented as we went along. That said, the field trips were interesting and the conversational style of the lectures was engaging.

Question 15- there are not alot of courses focused on urban sustainability or planning at FES. For students who have an interest in these issues areas, I would recommend this course. I would also suggest FES look at a way to expand curriculum focused in these topic areas.

Professor Kooris clearly has broad knowledge in the course area; I think the class would benefit from more explicit structure. Maybe more focused case studies or directly comparing policies in a class exercise could be useful. I think three hours is too long a block for lecture. I did not find the weekly assignments useful, and it also didn't make sense to give out grades for them after all assignments had been completed.

The course content was fascinating, but because the course was often structured as a discussion, the overarching framework was harder to grasp. I found structured presentations with slides to be helpful.

The course was interesting and learning from an experienced practitioner like David was terrific. The lectures tended to wander, and I had a hard time identifying the themes at some points (they blended together maybe a bit too much). Also was sometimes hard to tell what was David's opinion as opposed to general planning knowledge. I really appreciated his flexibility and availability. Both field trips were a lot of fun.

David did a fantastic job! I would have liked for the weekly assignments to be more rigorous, perhaps that might involve actually copying the format of a city plan. Starting the final paper earlier and discussing with peers might have been good too. Overall, I learned a ton and loved it!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: David knows A LOT. Just getting to hear his stories and about his experience was super informative.
It is practical to our everyday lives
The real-world experiences David spoke about were extremely interesting, and gave us a sense of the realities of working in planning.
The readings were well chosen except for maybe a handful. Both field trips really helped me understand topics from the class.
The opportunity to write a final paper on a topic of your choosing related to planning, and the readings.
David's real "hands on" experience with the material we were covering in class was very useful. He was able to give a first hand perspective on the topics many of us were interested in.
Kooris as a practitioner had really interesting and valuable, real world insights into planning. I greatly enjoyed the weekly discussions sections and final paper assignment.
The instructor has a lot of interesting stories to tell from his work experience
Field trips were interesting, and specific examples from Professor Kooris' professional experience were very useful.

The subject matter and real world knowledge the instructor brought to the classroom. In particular, the class on resilience was very well organized, with very interesting content. I also really enjoyed the field trips.
Learning from a practitioner was great. The resilience lecture was, in my opinion, by far the most engaging. Wish there could be a class on this entirely.
David's expertise

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Getting feedback/responses from David and the TF sometimes took a while. I didn't get grades on our weekly homework assignments until the end of the semester, when we didn't have any more to turn in. I would have liked something earlier so that I could have made changes to how I was doing the work.
N/A
More clarity on what is expected for assignments, and more timely regular feedback on weekly group assignments.

Some of the topics are very technical and if you don't know much background information it can be hard to understand examples. I think this class gave me exposure and basic knowledge, which isn't a bad thing. The group assignments were probably only helpful for the first two times.
Design of the syllabus and class requirements, and the design of the lectures vs. discussion time.

The course was somewhat disorganized at times and directions for assignments were fairly open ended. In addition, we spent most of the class listening to David lecture which was interesting, but three hour lectures can be tiring after a while. Perhaps mixing up the way students were learning in the class would be helpful.
Lecture organization. The professor's real world insights are valuable, but sometimes overall concepts can be lost in the story telling.
At the beginning, I felt that many acronyms were used in the class without explanation
Course structure. Direct comparisons (city to city, policy to policy) would be helpful.

Organization. Course discussions included a lot of tangents. While examples and stories are interesting, having a more structured framework would have been helpful. I would have liked to see more discussions and lectures surrounding social/environmental injustices in cities and a deeper analysis of what could be done differently.
Content should be more organized. More direct engagement with the readings.
The weekly assignments

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
NA
There was no lab or separate discussion section.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It is practical to our everyday lives
It is the perfect course for an introduction to urban planning, and essential for any path of study related to land use and planning.

This course taught me about planning- a topic I was not familiar with but am interested in learning more about. I think most students who take this class want to work in the policy/planning field and are looking for a better understanding of how that relates to their environmental interests specifically.
The subject matter is very relevant, considering how pressing environmental challenges are in urban regions.
I am new to planning and was curious to learn about the urban sector.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was interested in urban planning, and when I talked to David at the course expo I was excited to learn that he ran the CT resilience program.
The importance of urban planning in the future

I wanted to learn about the details of planning and understand the role it plays in policy making in city governments. I have an interest in water and transportation planning and it is one of the few classes at FES that covers those topics in a way that make sense for future government/ NGO professionals.
Land use decision making has crucial impacts for conservation. I wanted a real look into what goes into making these decisions in the planning process.
I am broadly interested in planning.
I would like to do research and policy work on environmental topics in cities.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I didn't know what to expect because I was totally unfamiliar with planning at the start of the semester. I learned a lot!
Yes, the course met my expectations
Yes
It surpassed my expectations, as far as gaining a large scale intro to urban planning, with in-depth scenarios from David's career experiences.
I probably learned a little less than I had hoped, but again, I think a big part of this is because how technical this subject can be (particularly related to zoning and financing).
Yes- we covered a variety of topics that were very useful.
Yes, though I feel like we scratched the surface of a lot of topic areas that I would like to explore more deeply.
More or less, yes. Did not exceed expectations, but certainly met them.
Yes, I learned a ton about policy!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Honestly I didn't get a lot out of the group assignments. It was nice getting to know FES students who aren't in my year/cohort though.
It was great working in a group. We discussed a lot and were able to under complex topics in the planning.
Different perspectives
Lack of clarity of expectations for the assignment.
It was helpful to think through key points of the readings together, and to hear what people have learned about planning from living in different parts of the world.

Advantages- it allowed for more class interaction and engagement on topics. Disadvantages- the assignments were vague and sometimes lacked feedback so it was hard to figure out if we were doing the weekly assignments the right way.

The group work could have benefitted from clearer direction and feedback. Our group didn't receive feedback until after the group work had been completed, making it impossible to improve, which was very frustrating. The benefit of the group work was that it created an opportunity for students to discuss material outside of the lecture time.

The weekly group assignment was not helpful at all for my group since we do not collectively has an interest in the same city. We ended up working on a city close by simple for the sake of choosing a city. However, we didn't know the city well enough and were not interested.
Not necessarily more useful than working alone.
Though my group was great, weekly group assignments were not as helpful because they became repetitive and expectations and key takeaways were not clearly defined.

Learned a lot of from one of my team mates, who had more background in the field than I did. That person was really wonderful to work with. My other team mate was not at all on board, didn't do the readings, barely his part of the project, and nearly plagiarized part of our submission (thankfully caught that before handing it in). In all group projects, there should be a more formalized way to provide feedback, as I don't think all of us should have benefited equally from the work we submitted.
Uneven work distribution and level of commitment
The downsides of group work almost always outweigh the advantages--this was no exception.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You'll learn a lot, but it's different than other courses. David is a practitioner, not a professor, so some things are structured differently.
Take the course, you won't regret it

Absolutely take it! If you have any interest in land use or urban planning, it is the perfect overview course. It is also a great course for people pursuing different areas of study, because it gives insights into how our world is structured around us. David Kooris is an excellent lecturer, and fills class with experiences from his career as well as the basics of urban planning.
This course gives you very real perspective (which is helpful) but can be a little disorganized and open ended. Be sure you are comfortable with that format before committing to the course.
This is a generally interesting course, and it is good for balancing out other, heavier workload courses.
Choosing a final paper topic that you're really passionate about and has a relatively narrow focus will enable you to better connect the concepts learned in the class.

David is great; ask him questions because he always has an answer and if he doesn't, he will find someone who does. He is very approachable and gives great advice. The course is good for beginnings, probably not recommended for students with a deeper background.
Learn from David's amazing stories!
